name: MIT OCW Economics
description: Over 100 courses covering all major fields of economics. Courses include prerequisites, recommended textbooks, lecture slides, and assignments. Undergraduate and graduate programs.

name: edX Economics
description: Introductory topics, few prerequisites.

name: Khan Academy: Economics
description: Elementary topics.

name: Academic Search
description: Search across .edu and other educational domains. These materials are more reliable than the big Internet.

name: Foundational Equations of Economics
description: These equations show principles behind "thinking like an economist". Graduate textbooks put these equiations in context.

name: IGM Economic Experts Panel
description: Top economists reflect on policy-related issues. Some answers contain useful details.

name: AEA Resources for Economists
description: A list of useful links maintained by the American Economic Association.

name: RePEc
description: Web services for economic researchers: bibliography, blog aggregator, new working papers, software.

name: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis: Web Services
description: A list of helpful services.

name: IDEAS RePEc
description: The largest database of economics publications (2,000,000 items). Searching through papers is easier with Google: site:ideas.repec.org <search term>. Index sources mentioned below.

name: NBER
description: Working papers by major researchers. Many of these papers get published in peer-reviewed journal.

name: SSRN Economics
description: Working papers, no journal publications.

name: Google Scholar
description: Searching academic literature in general. Features author pages and citation counters. If you look for economic writings only, IDEAS would be more powerful.

name: FRED2
description: 380,000 (macro) time series from 80 sources. Supports plugins for importing data into Excel, Stata, R, and others. Has a mobile app.

name: World Bank Data
description: International macro time series. Has data import plugins.

name: IMF Data
description: The standard reference for macro data.

name: Quandl
description: Aggregate financial and economic data from multiple sources. Some data vendors sell their data via this service. Good integration with statistical software.

name: MEDevEcon
description: Data related to development economics.

name: Monetary Economics: Data Sources
description: Overview of macro data sources.

name: OFFSTATS
description: Links to official data sources by country and subject.

name: International Open Government Dataset Search
description: Over 1,000,000 government datasets. When works, this service looks like this. Otherwise, you'll see a 403 error.

name: Dataset Search Engine
description: Google-based search over 200 data sources, including those mentioned here. You can use Google search operators here.

name: StackExchange Open Data
description: If you haven't found the data you were looking for, you can ask it here.

name: Reddit /r/datasets
description: One more place to request datasets.

name: LaTeX
description: Economists write in LaTeX because it handles mathematics and references better than Word or LibreOffice. If you write regularly, LaTeX is worth learning.

name: Beamer
description: A LaTeX class for presentations.

name: TikZ
description: An extension for drawing graphs. A how-to and a manual.

name: LyX
description: A free and simple editor for LaTeX.

name: Zotero
description: Bibliography management. Also install (a) Zotero browser plugin to import papers from RePEc to your library; (b) Zotero-LyX plugin to cite literature easily.

name: Git
description: A version control system. Useful if you want to revert changes done months ago or collaborate with other authors. DropBox also has version control, but Git is more explicit. A short intro. Or use GitHub Desktop if you like it simple.

name: Stata
description: An industry standard for statistical computations in economics. Free alternatives:

name: IPython
description: A Python-based environment. Econometric analysis requires SciPy, NumPy, statsmodels, and some other libraries installed. Consider installing Anaconda, which contains much of the needed stuff.

name: RStudio
description: A R-based environment. Many statistical R libraries are not available in other languages, so it's a pretty rich platform.

name: Matlab
description: An industry standard for modeling and numerical optimization in economics. Free alternatives:

name: Mathematica
description: Symbolic computations. Free alternative

name: GitHub
description: A repository for code and data. Publishing research here is not a common practice, but it's more convenient that alternatives (university home page, DropBox, etc.).

name: GitHub Pages
description: Simple static websites.

name: GitHub LFS
description: Large file storage.

name: IPython Notebooks
description: An interactive alternative to LaTeX and Word. See examples how notebooks look like in data-science-ipython-notebooks and the gallery.

name: Most common programs used by Economists
description: A community-managed list of common software.

name: Software for Researchers: New Data and Applications
description: Covers software mentioned above and some more.

name: How to efficiently manage a statistical analysis project?
Economist's View
description: Mark Thoma

name: Grasping Reality
description: Brad DeLong

name: Marginal Revolution
description: Tyler Cowen and Alex Tabarrok

name: VOX CEPR
description: Members of CEPR

name: Economics Blog Search
description: A Google-based search service for aforementioned blogs.

name: AEA Blog Directory
description: The list of major economic blogs.

name: StackExchange Economics
description: A Q&A website where you can ask and answer questions.

name: /r/GoodEconomics/
description: Selected pieces on economic issues.

name: /r/EconPapers/
description: Discussing economic papers.

name: QS World University Rankings by Subject 2016
description: Economics & Econometrics

name: Academic Ranking of World Universities in Economics / Business
American Economic Association: Graduate Training in Economics
description: Overview of the programs, requirements, and advices to those considering a PhD program in economics.

name: Job Openings for Economists
description: The job board by the American Economic Association.

name: Econ Jobs Postings
description: List of academic job openings.

name: Economics Job Market Rumors
description: List of job openings for economists. Informal.

name: davidrpugh
description: Institute for New Economic Thinking, Oxford Martin School; Oxford Mathematical Institute, Oxford, UK.

name: hmgaudecker
description: Universität Bonn, Bonn, Germany.

name: jstac
description: Australian National University, Canberra, Australia.

name: nathanlane
description: Institute for International Economic Studies, Stockholm, Sweden.

name: trickvi
description: Hagstofa Íslands, Iceland.

name: nealbob
description: Australian National University, Canberra, Australia.

name: economics-book
description: Economics Textbook (Openstax).

name: pyeconomics
description: Computational economics in Python.

name: QuantEcon
description: A library for quantitative economics.

name: quantecon_nyu_2016
description: Topics in Computational Economics

name: zice-2014
description: Course materials for Zurich Initiative for Computational Economics (ZICE) 2014.

name: VFI Toolkit
description: Matlab toolkit for Value Function Iteration on GPU.

name: Economics Games
description: Free online classroom games for teaching economics.

name: Top 100 Economics Blogs
description: Links to popular economics blogs, with brief descriptions.

name: Deveconodata Blogspot
description: Development economics datasets. Updated regularly.

name: fecon235
description: Computational tools for financial economics, Python code base and tutorials using Jupyter notebooks, includes data retrieval, graphics, and optimization.

name: Quantitative Economics
description: Lecture series by Thomas J. Sargent and John Stachurski using Python computational tools.
